I am superior is a type of excessive pride. I am equal is a type of pride. I am inferior is a type of debased pride. There is someone superior to me is a type of debased pride. There is someone equal to me is a type of pride. There is someone inferior to me is a type of excessive pride. There is no one superior to me is a type of pride. There is no one equal to me is a type of excessive pride. There is no one inferior to me is a type of debased pride.
Therefore, these nine arise from three types of pride: pride, excessive pride, and debased pride. They are distinguished by their sequence of activity and form three groups of three.
How can the type of pride that thinks I am not inferior be considered inflated?

There are those who, in a group of superior sentient beings they desire, know themselves to be extremely inferior, yet still respect themselves, like those who display good omens or the CÄá¹‡á¸Äla caste.
Although they know themselves to be despised by the world, when they hold to what they do while displaying good omens, they respect their own bodies and therefore become inflated.
In this way, these seven types of pride are eliminated.
Some other teachers say:

The pride of thinking oneself superior and the pride of thinking oneself equal are eliminated only by the path of insight, while the others are eliminated by both the paths of insight and cultivation.
In reality, it should be said that the seven kinds of pride are eliminated by both the paths of insight and cultivation. Therefore the Abhidharmasamuccaya can say,
â€œWe do not grasp the self as being identical with form, etc.â€
However, in regard to these five aggregates that are grasped, the seeds of the pride of thinking oneself superior and the seeds of craving are not yet eliminated.
Is it certain that when the seeds of the pride of thinking oneself superior, etc., that are eliminated by the path of cultivation have not yet been eliminated, they will appear?

This is not certain, because there are seeds that have already been eliminated that can appear, just as there is the seed of craving for sexual activity in one who has already eliminated the craving for sense desire.
There are seeds that, although not yet eliminated, definitely will not appear, just as there is no seed of the bonds of killing in a saint who has not yet eliminated the craving for sense desire.
The bond of killing is the bond that causes one to kill living beings.
The word â€œetc.â€ in the text refers to the bonds of stealing, sexual misconduct, and lying. There is the entire bond of delight in nonexistence and part of the bond of delight in existence.
What is meant by nonexistence?
It means that one delights in the nonexistence of the three realms of existence. This is called the bond of delight in nonexistence.
Therefore, this passage excludes the pure and the impermanent, because they are definitely not the basis of attachment.
One part of the thirst for existence is the desire to become a great nÄga king such as Anavatapta.
Although it is said to manifest as the king of the asuras, the northern continent of Uttarakuru, and the mindless celestials, etc.
Although these bonds of killing, etc., are eliminated by cultivation, the noble ones definitely do not manifest them. The reason for their non-manifestation will be explained later.
The same is true for the various kinds of pride, etc.
In the thirst for nonexistence, there is also that eliminated by the path of insight. The sÅ«tra speaks of it according to the circumstances. It is said that it is eliminated by cultivation.
As a sÅ«tra says, a certain type of person, oppressed by suffering, thinks in this way:
â€œI wish that after my death, I will be annihilated and cease to exist. How happy that would be!â€
This thirst only arises in dependence on the similarity of aggregates.
Why do the various kinds of pride exist in the noble ones, but the dharmas of pride, etc., are not manifested?
The Treatise says:
The various kinds of pride, etc., and the pride of self-conceit, are not good in the category of remorse.
The noble ones have them but do not give rise to them, because views and doubt increase them.
The treatise says:

The word etc. indicates that the entanglements such as killing, etc., the entire absence of love, and part of the love of existence, are not present in the noble ones, because the noble ones cultivate emptiness well, and because they well understand the principle of the connection between karma and its results.
The various types of pride, the pride of thinking I am, and bad remorse, although not yet eliminated by the noble ones, definitely do not occur in them.
This is because views and doubt increase them, and because views and doubt have already been eliminated and therefore do not occur again.

That is to say, the various types of pride and the pride of thinking I am are increased by the view of the aggregates as a person. The entanglements such as killing, etc., are increased by wrong views. The absence of love is increased by the view of annihilation. Part of the love of existence is increased by the view of permanence. Bad unwholesome remorse is increased by doubt. Therefore, although the noble ones have them that have not yet been eliminated, because they turn their backs on them and analyze them, they all definitely do not occur.
The remaining [entanglements] are not increased by views and doubt, and therefore, although the noble ones may possess them, they may still occur.
Among the ninety-eight latent afflictions, how many are universal and how many are not universal?
The verse says:
Those abandoned by seeing suffering and accumulation, associated with views and doubts,
And the universal ignorance not shared [with others], are universal in their own realm and stage.
Excluding the two views, the remaining nine are able to take the upper realms as objects.
Excluding acquisition, the rest that follow are also categorized as universal.
The treatise says:

Only the latent tendencies abandoned by seeing suffering and accumulation have the power to be universal, but not all of them. That is to say, only those associated with views, doubts, and the independent ignorance, not the others such as craving.
There are seven views and two doubts, and the associated ignorance is included in them.
There are two independent [types], thus making eleven.
In this way, these eleven are each able to be universal in their own realm and stage, in the five categories.

That is to say, in the dharmas of the five categories in one's own realm and stage, the latent tendencies that universally take them as objects give rise to defilements through being causes. Therefore, only these are established as universal. Speaking in terms of realms, there are thirty-three universals.
What is the meaning of the name â€œunique ignoranceâ€?

According to this interpretation, the meaning of â€œcommonâ€ is that of being mixed, and this ignorance is not common, and for that reason it is called â€œunique,â€ which means that it is not the same as the others.
As a scripture says,
The Buddha is not common to the Saá¹…gha.
This shows that the two treasures of the Buddha and the Saá¹…gha are not the same, because the Buddha is not common to the Saá¹…gha.
Ignorance is not common to the other propensities because it is not mixed with them.
Or, the meaning of â€œcommonâ€ is that of being universal.
This ignorance is not common, and for that reason it is called â€œunique,â€ because it is not associated with the other propensities.
Why is it that among the propensities eliminated by the paths of insight into the truths of suffering and its cause, only the latter are universal?

Only the latter are able to take as their objects all impure dharmas, and their mode of activity and power are firm and strong, and therefore they are able to be causes that generate the five classes of passions.

The passions that are eliminated by the vision of cessation and the vision of the path can only take impure things as objects, and their objects are different. Their power is not firm and strong and they are not able to act as causes to universally generate the five classes of passions. Therefore only the first two classes of passions have universal proclivities.

These universal proclivities have three meanings of universality, that is, they are universal as proclivities that are objects of the five classes of passions and are able to act as causes to universally generate defiled dharmas.
The dharmas associated with them have two meanings of universality, that is, they are universal in the above two meanings but lack the meaning of universality as proclivities.
The dharmas that are their concomitants have one meaning of universality, that is, they are universal as causes that universally generate defiled dharmas.
If universal proclivities are able to take the five classes of passions as objects, then the view of a real self takes as objects dharmas eliminated by the vision of the truths of cessation and path.
With regard to which of the four truths is it eliminated?
If it is eliminated by the vision of suffering, then craving, etc., should also be eliminated by the vision of suffering, because they also take the five classes of passions as objects.

Also, just as wrong views take as objects dharmas eliminated by the vision of the truths of cessation and path, so also the view of grasping views takes as objects the pure dharmas of the truths of cessation and path, because it is directly deluded and deluded with regard to cessation and the path and is therefore eliminated by the vision of cessation and the path.

In the same way, the view of the aggregates as a person is also a direct delusion, because it is deluded about cessation and the path, and therefore should be seen as eliminated by the path of insight.

Or you should explain the reason for the difference.ğŸ”½Also, just as the view of annihilation and the view of eternalism are eliminated by the path of insight into cessation and the path, in the same way, the view of the aggregates as a person should be so eliminated by the path of insight into cessation and the path.

Or, just as the view of the aggregates as a person is eliminated by the complete understanding of its object, in the same way, the view of holding to mere rules and rituals should be so eliminated by the path of insight into cessation and the path.
Both of these two positions are not accepted by the schools, and therefore your argument is unreasonable.
This must be so, because there is a difference in meaning.
First, as for the example, craving, etc., should also be eliminated by the path of insight into suffering, because they also take the five categories as objects.
Or, this is just an example to refute the view of the aggregates as a person. The principle should also apply to those included in the five categories.
This example is unreasonable, because craving, etc., should also suddenly take the five categories as objects in a single moment.
That is to say, in a single moment, the view of the aggregates as a person suddenly takes the five categories of feeling, etc., as its object, as self and what belongs to self.

It is not reasonable to say that the substance of the view of the real existence of the self in a single moment of thought is divided into five parts, because craving, etc., are all passions of the specific category. There is not even a single moment of thought that suddenly takes two parts as an object, much less five. Therefore the example is not established.

The later example says that just as the pride that takes as its object the truths of cessation and path is eliminated by the path of insight into the truths of cessation and path, the same is true of the view of grasping dharmas as supreme that takes cessation and path as its object. Since both are directly deluded and deluded about cessation and path, they should also be eliminated by insight into the truths of cessation and path.
This also is not reasonable, because the view of the real existence of the self cannot praise and deprecate the view of cessation and path.
Also, the object of this view has no divisions.

The view of the real existence of the self does not first praise and deprecate the view of cessation and path and then consider it to be the self. Also, it does not take as its object a limited part of the realm of objects.
The pride that takes as its object dharmas that are supreme must praise and deprecate the false view that denies cessation and path and only then consider it to be supreme.
Since the meaning of taking as an object is different, it cannot be used as an example.

However, when the view of the real existence of the self sees the truth of suffering, it completely knows the object and is completely and forever eliminated, unlike the pride that takes as its object dharmas that are supreme.
There is a separate reason for this, because the objects, modes of activity, and understanding are not the same.

That is, the aggregates of the three realms that are to be eliminated by the path of insight into suffering are not the self, and so on up to the aggregates that are to be eliminated by cultivation are not the self. Their characteristics are also the same.
Therefore, when suffering is seen, the view of self does not arise, and the view of self that has suffering as its object is eliminated.
But this is not so for the view of grasping a superior moral quality. One may consider a lesser dharma to be superior.

Consequently, the view of grasping a superior moral quality that accompanies the view of the aggregates as a self, although it has as its object dharmas eliminated by the paths of insight into cessation and path, is eliminated only by the path of insight into suffering, because it is gross, just as the view of the aggregates as a self is. It is like the view that has as its object dharmas eliminated by the path of cultivation.

The view of grasping a superior moral quality that accompanies the views that deny cessation and the path, although it also has as its object dharmas eliminated by those two paths, is eliminated only by the path of cultivation, because it is extremely subtle in relation to the former, because it is not included in the understanding of the activities of pleasure and purity, because it is attracted by the ignorance that does not desire to eliminate cessation and the path, and because it is the false view that considers the most superior. Even though the object is completely understood in the state of insight into suffering, still it is eliminated only when the object is eternally eliminated.

Therefore, the view of grasping at inferior views is not like the view of grasping at the self, which is completely and permanently eliminated when one sees suffering. Therefore, the principle of the distinctions in elimination is established. Or, it is eliminated by seeing cessation and seeing the path.ğŸ”½Each of the views of grasping at inferior views is of three kinds, that is, eliminated by seeing suffering, seeing the origination of suffering, and seeing cessation and the path, because one is eliminated by each of the three.
If one grasps the part of the effect as superior, it is eliminated by seeing the truth of the origination of suffering.
If one grasps the part of the cause as superior, it is eliminated by seeing the truth of the origination of suffering.

If one only grasps that as true understanding, not unilaterally grasping the part of the cause or the part of the effect, then it is eliminated together with that which is grasped, according to the circumstances. Therefore, the elimination of the view of grasping at inferior views is not like the view of grasping at the self.

If the view of grasping at the self, the grasping at precepts and vows, and the view of grasping at inferior views all suddenly take the five categories as their objects, they are called universal. Then, universal [contaminants] are not only those. Because where there is the activity of the view of the self, there must arise self-love and self-conceit.

If in a certain place there is the activity of the view of purity and superiority, in that place one must necessarily aspire to it and be conceited about it. Then, love and conceit must also be universal.
This objection is not reasonable.
Although it is seen that they arise through the power of the view of self and possessions, these two kinds are limited in scope. For this reason, the omnipresent only number eleven.
The previously mentioned eleven are able to universally operate in their own realms, stages, and five categories. Are there any omnipresent [contaminants] in other realms and other stages?
In order to distinguish them, it is said that they are in one's own realm and one's own stage. There are also omnipresent [contaminants] in other realms and other stages.
Among the eleven, excluding the views of self and possessions, the remaining nine kinds are also able to take the higher realms as objects.
The word higher correctly refers to the higher realms and higher stages, and also shows that there are no latent contaminants that take the lower realms as objects.
If they took the lower realms as objects, then one would have to universally know the destruction of the realms. Because the higher objects are superior, there is no error in taking them as objects.

For example, in the desire realm, the wrong views that are eliminated by insight into suffering deny the suffering results in the form and formless realms as non-existent. The view of holding as paramount takes them as the most supreme. The view of holding as means takes them as causes when they are not causes. Doubt is indecisive. Ignorance is not understanding.
The contaminants eliminated by insight into the origin should be explained as appropriate.
The same should be understood for the formless realm as object.
According to the realms, one should consider and distinguish according to the stages.
However, in the desire realm up to the fourth trance state, there are universal permeating mental activities that take the upper realms and upper stages as objects.

In the three formless realms, there is no taking the upper realms as objects. In the peak of existence, there are none of the two kinds. Although there are proclivities that universally take the upper realms as objects,

in reality there is no sudden taking of the upper realms as objects, because the objects of the various realms and stages in the lower realms are objects of the proclivities and are also objects of the permeations.

If the objects of the various realms and stages in the upper realms are objects of the proclivities, they are not objects of the permeations. It is impossible for a single moment of a proclivity to have a place where it is a proclivity and a place where it is not a proclivity.
Do not say that the same is true of the associated mental activities.
Must the upper realms and stages be suddenly taken as objects?
They are not necessarily suddenly taken as objects, but may be taken separately or generally.
Why do the views of a real self and the real extremity not take the upper realms as objects, but take other realms and stages as objects?
Because it is impossible for the principle of self and that which belongs to the self and the views of annihilation and eternity to be established.
That is, one born in this realm and this stage does not take the aggregates of another realm and stage as a self, because it is impossible for there to be two selves.
Because it is impossible to grasp a self, it is impossible to grasp that which belongs to a self, because that which is grasped must arise from grasping a self.
The two extreme views arise from the view of the aggregates as a self, and therefore they also cannot be associated with realms and stages other than that of the aggregates.
Consequently, it is established that only nine can be associated with the upper stages.
Other masters say that

the two extreme views arise through the power of craving and grasping, because one grasps what is appropriated as oneâ€™s own, because one takes as an object a presently seen dharma, and therefore they cannot be associated with the upper stages.
If one born in the realm of desire takes the great BrahmÄ as a self and a permanent dharma, to which of the views does this belong?
In reality, these two are not views but erroneous knowledge induced by the two extreme views of the aggregates as a self.

It is directly perceived that the aggregates are impermanent, and one infers that the self is also impermanent. One who is born in the desire realm does not grasp the self as being MahÄbrahmÄ, nor does one grasp MahÄbrahmÄ as being the self. Therefore, this is not the view of self.
Because there is no view of self, there is also no extreme view, because extreme views necessarily arise following the view of self.
Because no other views take this mode of activity, this is a wrong view induced by the extreme views of self and of what belongs to self.
Are the characteristics of the omnipresent only the latent afflictions?ğŸ”½No.
What then?
The omnipresent characteristics are the omnipresent latent afflictions, as well as the feelings, etc., and the arising, etc., that accompany them, because they have the same effect.
However, among the accompanying factors, only the acquisitions are excluded, because the acquisitions and the acquired do not have the same effect.
Therefore, the omnipresent causes and the latent afflictions, when compared, have four distinctions in the tetralemma.
Among the ninety-eight latent afflictions, how many take contaminated things as objects and how many take uncontaminated things as objects?
In verse, it says:
The six kinds of ignorance associated with wrong views and doubts that are eliminated by the paths of insight into cessation and into the path,
and the independent ignorance, can take the pure as their objects.
Among them, those that take cessation as their objects take only the cessation of their own stage as their objects.

Those that take the path as their objects take the six or nine stages as their objects, because they are the counteragents to the various kinds of passions and because they are the causes of each other.
Greed, hatred, pride, and the two kinds of clinging do not have the pure as their objects,
because one must be separated from the objects of the first two, and because the objects of the latter two are pure and superior.

The treatise says:ğŸ”½Only the three kinds of wrong views and the two kinds of doubts that are eliminated by the paths of insight into cessation and into the path, and the ignorance associated with them and independent of them, are each divided into three, making six kinds that can take the pure as their objects.

That is, the three kinds of wrong views and the two kinds of doubt eliminated by the paths of insight into cessation and into the path are associated with ignorance, which is included in them. There are two kinds of independent ignorance, making six kinds in all.
These six kinds of ignorance in the various realms and stages that can take cessation and the path as their objects are called those that take the pure as their objects.
The rest take the impure as their objects. It is not necessary to mention this, since it is already understood.
As for these contaminants that take the pure as their objects, how many realms do they take as their objects?

Those that take cessation as their objects take their own realm as their object. That is, contaminants of the realm of desire that take cessation as their object take as their objects only the cessation resulting from the contemplation of the truths of the realm of desire. Up to the summit of existence, contaminants that take cessation as their object take as their objects only the cessation resulting from the contemplation of the truths of the summit of existence.
Those that take the path as their object take six or nine realms as their objects.

That is, contaminants of the realm of desire that take the path as their object take as their objects only the path of the class of the cognition of the doctrine of the six stages, because the path of the class of the cognition of the doctrine of the realm of desire and that which is able to eliminate the other stages all take it as their object.

The contaminants of the eight stages of the realm of form and the formless realm that take the path as their object each take as their objects the path of the class of subsequent cognition of the nine stages, because the path of the class of subsequent cognition of the realm of form and the formless realm and that which is able to eliminate the other stages all take it as their object.
Why is it that wrong views that deny suffering and the cause are contaminants of the realm of desire that take nine stages as their objects?
The first trance state can take as its object the eight stages up to the peak of existence, only taking the wrong views that slander cessation of those stages as its object.
Within the nine stages, each can only take as its object the cessation of its own stage. This has a reason.
What is the reason?

It is said that if a dharma is moistened by craving of a certain stage, and the view of self of that stage grasps it as self or what belongs to self, then the cessation of those dharmas becomes the object of the wrong views abandoned by the path of seeing of that stage.

This is explained as follows: if there are any conditioned factors that are the objects of self-love and the view of self of a certain stage, then due to attachment to the conditioned factors of that stage, if one hears that there is cessation of the conditioned factors of that stage, one will give rise to the wrong views of that stage and deny their existence.
There is no attachment to lower [stages] within higher [stages]. How could lower wrong views deny the cessation of higher [stages]?

Although the stages and realms are mutually causal, the suffering and accumulation of the nine stages mutually impel each other. Moreover, the cause is established based on birth, and they mutually become causes for each other.

It is possible that one instance of wrong views may have as its object the cessation of many stages, because cessation is not related to the realm of desire, nor is it a cause of it. Therefore wrong views that deny cessation only have as their object the cessation of their own stage.
However, all good knowledge that understands objects is rational and may suddenly have as its object the cessation of many stages.
The arising of wrong views is confused with regard to objects, and one is obstructed by firm adherence and is unable to have as an object all stages.
Why is it that wrong views that take cessation as an object are either general or specific, but this is not so with regard to the path?
Because the antidote is different and they are mutually causal.

That is, although the path as an object is different in the various stages, it is still related to the other stages and is a cause for the other stages. Therefore, because of this, wrong views may generally have as their object the six and nine stages. Cessation is not a cause and is only related to its own stage.

Isnâ€™t it the case that the path of the two classes of knowledge of the Dharma and the knowledge of other natures is also mutually causal? Wrong views of lower and upper stages should be able to have as their objects the paths of the classes of knowledge of the Dharma and the knowledge of other natures, just as there is no obstruction to having as an object suffering and its causes in the various stages.
This criticism is not reasonable, because it is not an antidote.

If this is so, then the path of the class of knowledge of dharmas in the sixth stage would not be of the realm of desire, because the class of knowledge of dharmas in the five stages above is not an antidote to dharmas of the realm of desire.
The stage of noninterruption is not completely affiliated with the upper stages, because it is not an antidote to desire.
That which is an antidote to desire is not completely so, because it is to be combated by patience.

In the same way, wrong views in the realm of form and the formless realm should also be able to take as objects the path of the class of knowledge of dharmas, because there is a path of the class of knowledge of dharmas that is an antidote to the realm of form and the formless realm.
If it is said that the class of knowledge of dharmas is not completely an antidote to that, because the class of knowledge of dharmas of suffering and accumulation is not an antidote to that,
it is also not completely able to be an antidote to the realm of form and the formless realm, because it is not able to be an antidote to that which is eliminated by the path of insight.

The knowledge of dharmas of the first class is not able to be an antidote to the first class of the passions, because it is not the antidote to this, and the class of knowledge of dharmas is not the object of that.

Then you must admit that wrong views of the realm of form and the formless realm cannot take the nine stages as their object, because they are not able to universally counteract the passions of the two upper realms.
That is, the path of subsequent knowledge of the second trance state, etc., is not able to be the antidote to the passions of the first trance state, etc.
The first trance state, etc., are also not universal, and the two sections of investigation are as explained previously.

Also, the propensities of the three realms that take the truth of the path as their object are not what are eliminated by the patience that is knowledge of suffering, etc. Therefore, the view that denies the truth of the path should not be able to take the six or nine stages as its object.

In reality, these nets of error do not exist, because knowledge of the law and subsequent knowledge are different in kind from each other. The classes of knowledge of the law and subsequent knowledge are the same in kind in their elimination of passions. They are causes of each other and objects of each other.
That is, the class of the path of knowledge of the law is the same in kind as the antidote to the passions of the realm of desire that take the truth of the path as their object.

The paths of the same species are the objects of the passions of the realm of desire that have the path as their object, because they are the reciprocal causes and reciprocal conditions of each other, even though they are not antidotes. The path of the class of the knowledge of the law is not the object of the passions of the realm of desire that have the path as their object, because even though the path of the class of subsequent knowledge is the reciprocal cause of the class of the knowledge of the law, the two classes are different in species because of the difference of the doors of their antidotes, and because they are not the conditions as objects of each other.

In the same way, it is to be inferred that the passions of the realm of form and of the formless realm that have the path as their object can also have as their objects the class of the knowledge of the law of the realm of form and the formless realm.

That is, even though there are some paths of the class of the knowledge of the law in those two realms that are the antidotes of some passions of those realms and are reciprocal causes of each other, still, because the doors of their antidotes are different in species, and because they are not the conditions as objects of each other, they are not the objects of the passions of the two realms that have the path as their object.

The paths of the class of subsequent knowledge in the nine stages are of the same species, and they are reciprocal causes and reciprocal conditions of each other, because they are the same in their class of antidotes. Even though they are not antidotes, they can be the objects of the passions of the eight upper stages that have the path as their object.
Therefore the principle expressed in the verse is established.
Why are craving, hatred, pride, and the two kinds of grasping eliminated by the path of insight and not by the pure path?
Because those who delight in seeking true liberation must definitely abandon the affliction of craving.
If one grasps the pure as an object, it is like the desire for good dharmas, because one seeks nirvana and the holy path. Those who seek liberation should not abandon craving.
Moreover, the truths of cessation and path would be objects to be eliminated, because the Buddha said that the object of abandoning craving is called elimination.
As a scripture says:
If you can eliminate craving in form, form is also called eliminated.
Moreover, one can abandon craving only by seeing faults in the object of craving.
If one admits that there is craving that grasps the pure as an object, then when one sees faults in cessation and the path, craving would be abandoned.
This view is not pure, so how can it eliminate delusions?
Moreover, craving can only arise by seeing merits in the object of craving.

If you admit that craving can have pure dharmas as objects, then when one contemplates the pure dharmas of cessation, tranquillity, etc., craving should increase. How can you eliminate the passions on the basis of this contemplation?
If pure dharmas do not eliminate the passions, then birth and death will be endless. Therefore we know that craving does not have pure dharmas as objects.
Hatred can arise only in regard to things that are harmful, but pure dharmas are free of the characteristics of harmfulness. Therefore hatred cannot arise in regard to pure dharmas.
Also, the characteristic of the proclivity of hatred is that it is coarse and evil, but pure dharmas are extremely subtle and wonderful. Therefore hatred cannot occur in regard to them.
The proclivity of pride is characterized by a lofty bearing and is by nature not calm and quiet, but pure dharmas are extremely calm and quiet and do not give rise to a lofty bearing.
Also, one who gives rise to pride thinks,
I have attained this dharma.
Pure dharmas are not able to be objects and give rise to such pride, because pure dharmas are able to cure pride.
If the two graspings can have as objects the pure, then they would be the same as right views, because the pure is the true, excellent nature.
Since the two graspings are not inverted, they should not be eliminated by the path of insight. Therefore the two graspings do not have the pure as an object.

If this is so, then there is no error in the case of the latent tendency of hatred that arises with regard to wrong views, etc., that slander nirvÄá¹‡a, because it is said that the object is the same.

The mind that is averse to dharmas with faults is in accord with the proper way of conduct, because one should be distant from them. Therefore hatred is not eliminated by the path of insight into the truths of cessation and path. There is no such error.
Because the person who is ignorant of the characteristics of cessation generates hatred toward the slanderer.
That is, having grasped elsewhere that there is liberation, he then generates a mind of intolerance toward the slander of true liberation.

Therefore one who is ignorant of the characteristics of true cessation generates extreme aversion toward wrong views, etc., that slander cessation, and hatred is eliminated by the path of insight into the truth of cessation.

Those who are not ignorant of the characteristics of true cessation, when they give rise to aversion to the false views that slander cessation, etc., it is not the underlying tendency of anger, but rather it is included in the wholesome roots of non-greed.
Moreover, it is like someone who has many illnesses in their abdomen. In order to save their life, even if they eat delicious food, because it is mixed with illness, it all becomes harmful.
For someone without illness in their abdomen, whatever they eat is beneficial to their body and does no harm.

In the same way, if there are those who, in what is not cessation, falsely take it to be cessation and give rise to craving and love, because their continuity is defiled, the aversion that arises to the false views that slander cessation, etc., are all said to be eliminated by seeing cessation.

The anger that arises from the dharmas of false views, etc., if there are those who, in accordance with principle, know true cessation to be true cessation and have no craving and love, because their continuity is pure, the aversion that arises to the false views that slander cessation, etc., is all without fault.

How can one not believe that there is hatred that takes the uncontaminated as its object? Is it not the case that this hatred is known to exist in the world?
There are non-Buddhists who say that in nirvana, the faculties are eternally extinguished, which is a great loss.
Therefore, I do not delight in seeking it.
This is originally not hatred, but rather a wrong view.

Therefore, the Abhidharma treatise says that regarding pleasure, to consider it suffering is eliminated by seeing cessation, and is included in wrong views. The principle must be so, because all suffering is eternally extinguished only in the most blissful place.
The most blissful place is only true nirvana.
This word most blissful indicates ultimate bliss.
